The perpetrators should be charged and prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law for what they have done ‚Äì and we can all be thankful that our Bomb Squad/EOD experts are right there, helping out in our communities across the country. (End)

These men and women are absolute experts and are who we want at these scenes/in these situations when called for. They are going to be able to assist any/all law enforcement agencies with granular data to catch the person(s) who have done this

It is my hope that when things like this happen, we will remember those who get these calls, that they are heading full steam ahead to the threat, hoping to render it inert, diffuse it, or, if called for, detonate without any possible collateral damage.

May be dealing with.  They can also put on significant protective gear to guard themselves against a blast that would otherwise harm or potentially cause fatal injuries (see my previous tweets for pictures of these two examples)

Depending on the description of the device and even if there isn‚Äôt much of a description, they can now deploy robotic equipment that can go inside to a scene/location and provide live video of what they...

These experts who get these calls have a multitude of tools and resources now to assess the scene/device, more so than when I would join local law enforcement many years ago. We would have to get "eyes" on it directly to proceed
We had to do all we could to ensure the least amount of harm possible to civilians and our unit as we assessed the device and what needed to be done. Initial Success, or Total Failure
When I got called for different circumstances/situations, we had to determine what kind of device we were dealing with, its potential for harm, and how to secure the area around the device/munition

There is no consideration for any other factor when they get the call about a device other than to determine what they are dealing with and what the immediate next steps should be to prevent harm/injuries
The slogan we operated by in my unit was ‚ÄúInitial Success or Total Failure‚Äù and that is exactly what these individuals think of when they get the call of an IED/or explosive device
Quite literally ‚Äì they are trained to handle a bomb of ANY kind and what to do with that device in the circumstances that they find it in and determine what to do accordingly
All of these men and women who are a part of the bomb squads/bomb disposal units who get these calls are some of the best trained and are experts in how to handle a bomb of any kind, in any situation
As a former bomb disposal technician, I wanted to share some personal insight about what goes on in situations like we have seen the last few days based on my own previous experience (Thread)

Federal Disaster Assistance for SuperTyphoon Yutu is NOT available to CNMI residents until a Major Disaster Declaration is requested by the Governor & approved by the President. Gov. Torres & his leadership are currently coordinating with federal partners on the request.

FEMA Disaster Recovery Centers (DRCs) that were opened for the Presidential Declaration pertaining to Typhoon Mangkhut will remain closed until further notice. Once a thorough assessment is made, DRCs will reopen or relocate.

Transportation (cont'd)
- Saipan: Airport sustained significant damage; most flights cancelled; 
- Tinian: Airport runway now usable; some roads opening as debris is removed
- Rota: Airport assessment underway; initial report damage appears limited to debris on the runway

Transportation
- Ports inaccessible; all ports remain closed. 
- Roads: Many areas inaccessible due to debris

Energy
- Widespread power outage; generators requested. No power on Tinian.
- Commonwealth Utility Corporation (CUC) estimates 21 days of fuel available
- U.S. Army Corp of Engineers continues to work with CUC on power restoration

Health & Medical
- Tinian Medical Center closed due to extensive damage; No patients were present.
- Saipan hospital & Rota Medical Center running on generator power
- U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Health & Medical Task Force (14 staff) on their way to Saipan

- Tinian (cont'd)
Department of Defense to deliver additional supplies, food and water on 10/26

- Rota
2 shelters available
79 occupants

Shelters are open on each island:
- Saipan
15 shelters available, 6 @ capacity
533 occupants
FEMA to provide additional food, water equipment & supplies

- Tinian
3 shelters available, only 1 opened due to damage - occupants relocated to the opened shelter
45 occupants

Food Water and Shelter
- CNMI has 14 days of commodities; requesting additional supply from FEMA
- Water: Saipan water service restoration timeline unknown; system was shut down for the storm

The process by which the Governor determines whether to request a Disaster Declaration is currently underway. However, until/unless such a Declaration is requested  issued, residents impacted by Yutu should not yet apply for disaster assistance pertaining to Yutu-related damages.
The President has previously issued an Emergency Declaration, allowing FEMA and other Federal agencies to provide the support listed above.
- FEMA is bringing additional staff to coordinate air operations with the US Dept. of Defense and others supporting response and recovery operations throughout CNMI.
- The CNMI Public Safety Radio System is offline; CNMI & FEMA Operations have established a Communications Task Force to address this and other communication issues.

- Saipan‚Äôs hospital and Rota‚Äôs medical clinic are open and operating and have beds available.

- CUC is working with the US Army Corps of Engineers on permanent power restoration

- US Health & Human Services Disaster Medical Assistance Team is on the way to CNMI to support medical facilities, as needed.

-Although the hospital on Tinian incurred structural damage, no patients were inside at the time

Updates from CNMI, FEMA and the Federal family of agencies on the ground working on recovery: 

- FEMA and the US Dept. of Defense are supporting a request from CNMI, on behalf of Tinian, for food and water.
